adjusting: Picking up the object: The person reaches out with their hand and grasps the object.
Holding the object: The person maintains a firm grip on the object with their hand.
Adjusting the object: The person manipulates the object in some way, such as twisting, turning, or bending it.
Releasing the object: The person lets go of the object and it falls back to the ground or the person's hand.
Putting the object down: The person places the object back on a surface or in its original location.
assembling: Opening the package: The person removes the object from its packaging, which may involve tearing, cutting, or removing a protective cover.
Examining the parts: The person inspects the object and its parts to ensure they are complete and in good condition.
Assembling the object: The person puts the parts together according to the instructions, which may involve fastening, connecting, or aligning different components.
Testing the object: The person checks the object to ensure it functions properly and all the parts are securely in place.
Storing the object: The person places the assembled object in a suitable location, such as a shelf, drawer, or storage container, where it will be easily accessible and protected from damage.
blocking: Hand positioning: The person's hands may be placed in front of their body, with fingers or palms facing the object they are blocking.
Body posture: The person may be standing with their feet shoulder-width apart, knees slightly bent, and weight distributed evenly on both feet.

Focus: The person's attention is likely directed towards the object they are blocking, indicating their concentration on the task.
Physical barrier: The person's body may be positioned in such a way that it forms a physical barrier between themselves and the object, preventing it from passing through.

drying: Holding the object: The person is holding the object to be dried, typically with one or both hands, to keep it stable and prevent it from falling or slipping.

Carrying: The person moves the object from one location to another, either by holding it in their hand(s) or by using additional support, such as a tray or a bag.
pointing: Hand gesture: The person is using their hand to point at the object, which is a common way to draw attention to something.

Finger movement: The person is using their fingers to indicate the direction or location of the object, which is often used when pointing at something that is farther away or not directly in front of them.
Eye contact: The person is looking at the object and directing their gaze towards it, which can be a subtle way of pointing without physically touching the object.
Body language: The person may be using their body language, such as leaning forward or taking a step towards the object, to emphasize their point and draw attention to it.
Verbal cues: The person may be using verbal cues, such as saying "look at this" or "see over here," to indicate the object they are pointing at.
pouring: Grasping the object: The person holds the object in their hand or hands.
Lifting the object: The person uses their hands to lift the object off the surface it was sitting on.
Pouring the object: The person tilts the object and pours its contents into a container or onto a surface.
Stabilizing the object: The person uses their hands to stabilize the object as it pours, to prevent it from tipping over or spilling.
Releasing the object: The person releases the object after it has finished pouring, allowing it to drop back onto the surface it was sitting on.
pulling: Hand grasping the object: The person's hand can be seen holding onto the object, indicating that they are pulling it.
Arm extending: The person's arm can be seen extending outward, indicating that they are exerting force to pull the object.
Body posture: The person's body posture may change as they bend their knees and lean forward to apply more force to the object.
Tension in the object: The object being pulled may show signs of tension or strain, indicating that the person is applying a significant amount of force.
Movement of the object: The object being pulled may start to move, indicating that the person is successfully pulling it.
pushing: Hand placement: The person's hands can be seen gripping the object and applying force to push it.
Arm movement: The person's arm can be seen extending and bending as they push the object.
Body posture: The person's body may lean forward or to the side as they push the object, with their weight transferred to the front foot.
Leg movement: The person's legs may move slightly as they push the object, with the front foot pushing against the ground and the back foot lifting off the ground.
Object movement: The object being pushed will move in the direction the person is facing, as a result of the force applied by the person's hands, arms, and body.
racing: Running: The person is actively moving their legs and using their body to propel themselves forward.
Focusing: The person is concentrating on the object they are racing and the path they need to take to reach it as quickly as possible.
Strategizing: The person may be planning their route, deciding on the best approach to take, and anticipating any obstacles or changes in the course.
Balancing: The person may need to maintain their balance while running at high speeds, especially if the course is uneven or has obstacles.
Sprinting: The person may need to sprint at the end of the race to gain an advantage over their competitors and reach the object as quickly as possible.
reading: Picking up the object: The person reaches out and grasps the object with their hands.
Holding the object: The person supports the object with their hands, maintaining a firm grip.
Examining the object: The person closely inspects the object, possibly rotating or turning it over to view different sides.
Handling the object: The person manipulates the object, for example, by opening it, closing it, or moving it from one location to another.
Putting the object down: The person releases the object and places it back on a surface or in its original location.
releasing: Hand grasping the object: The person's hand can be seen holding the object, indicating that they are about to release it.
Arm extending: The person's arm can be seen extending, suggesting that they are in the process of releasing the object.
Finger positioning: The person's fingers can be seen positioning themselves to let go of the object, indicating that the release is about to occur.
Eye contact: The person may be looking in the direction they are releasing the object, ensuring that it goes where they want it to.
Body posture: The person's body posture may change as they prepare to release the object, with their weight shifting forward and their body positioning itself for the release.
repairing: Inspecting the object: The person examines the object to identify the issue and determine the necessary repairs.
Gathering tools and materials: The person collects the tools and materials needed for the repair, such as screwdrivers, wrenches, and replacement parts.
Disassembling the object: The person takes the object apart to access the internal components and perform the necessary repairs.
Performing the repairs: The person fixes the issue by replacing or repairing the damaged parts, using the tools and materials gathered in step 2.
Reassembling the object: The person puts the object back together, making sure all the parts are securely fastened and functioning properly.
riding: Holding onto the object for support.
Looking in the direction of travel.
Adjusting the position of the object to maintain stability.
rowing: Pulling the oar: The most obvious action involved in rowing is pulling the oar through the water. This motion requires strength and coordination to maintain a steady rhythm and propel the boat forward.
Sitting in the seat: A person rowing an object must sit in the seat of the boat and maintain a proper posture to ensure stability and control.

Using the legs: Rowers often use their legs to push off the ground and generate power for the stroke. This motion helps to propel the boat forward and can be an important part of the rowing technique.

Stabilizing the boat: While rowing, a person must also work to stabilize the boat by keeping it upright and balanced. This requires constant adjustments and coordination to maintain a smooth and steady rowing motion.

Catching the oar: At the end of each stroke, the rower must catch the oar and prepare for the next stroke. This action requires good hand-eye coordination and timing to ensure a smooth and efficient rowing motion.
running: The person's arms are outstretched in front of them, with their hands gripping the object.
The person's legs are moving quickly, propelling them forward as they run with the object.
The person's body is leaning slightly forward, with their head down and eyes focused on the path ahead.
The person's breathing is quick and shallow, as they exert themselves to run with the object.
The person's muscles are tense and flexed, as they use their strength to move the object quickly and efficiently.
sailing: Holding the object: The person is holding the object, which could be a sail or a rope, in their hands.
Pointing: The person is pointing towards something, possibly indicating a direction or a specific location.
Looking up: The person is looking up, possibly observing the sky or the surroundings for any changes in weather or wind conditions.
Bending down: The person is bending down, possibly to pick up an object or to examine something on the ground.
Walking: The person is walking, possibly moving towards a different location on the boat or the shore.
scratching: The person's hand making contact with the object.
The person's fingers gripping the object.
The person's hand moving across the object.
The object being scratched leaving a mark or removing a layer of material.
serving: Preparing to serve: The person reaches for the object, holding it in their hand or grasping it with both hands.
Serving the object: The person swings their arm and releases the object, sending it towards the intended target.
Following through: After releasing the object, the person's arm continues its motion, finishing in a follow-through position.
Catching the object: If the object is hit back towards the server, they must quickly react and catch it with their hands or gloves.
Returning the object: After catching the object, the person must quickly return it to the server, either by throwing or hitting it back towards them.
setting: Picking up the object: The person reaches out with their hand and grasps the object.
Holding the object: The person maintains a firm grip on the object with their hand.
Lifting the object: The person uses their strength to lift the object off the surface it was on.
Carrying the object: The person moves the object from one location to another while maintaining control of it.
Placing the object: The person carefully sets the object down on a surface, ensuring it doesn't fall or slide off.
shearing: Gripping the object: The person holds the object firmly in their hands to maintain control and stability during the shearing process.
Positioning the object: The person positions the object at the desired angle and location for shearing, ensuring that the cutting path is clear and accurate.
Applying pressure: The person applies pressure to the object using a shearing tool, such as a pair of scissors or a razor blade, to cut through the material.
Cutting the object: The person uses the shearing tool to make a clean, precise cut along the desired path, creating a smooth and even edge.
Removing the object: After the cutting is complete, the person carefully removes the object from the surface it was sheared from, ensuring that no remnants or debris are left behind.
signing: Holding the object: The person holds the object in their hand or hands while signing.
Positioning the hand: The person positions their hand or hands above the object, with the signing hand typically above the object.
Making contact: The person makes contact with the object using their signing hand, either by touching the object directly or by using a tool such as a pen or stylus.
Signing: The person signs the object using their hand or hands, using the appropriate signing movements and gestures to convey the intended meaning.
Releasing the object: The person releases the object after signing it, either by dropping it or by placing it back on a surface.
sipping: Raising the object to the mouth.
Bringing the object to the mouth.
Placing the object on the lips.
Lowering the object back down after taking a sip.
Holding the object steady while sipping.
sitting at: Hand on object: The person's hand is placed on the object, indicating that they are interacting with it in some way.
Eye contact: The person is looking at the object, which suggests that they are focused on it and possibly considering its purpose or function.
Body posture: The person's body posture, such as sitting up straight or leaning forward, can indicate their level of interest and engagement with the object.
Movement: The person may be moving their hand or body in some way, such as picking up the object, examining it, or manipulating it.
Expression: The person's facial expression, such as a frown or a smile, can provide clues about their emotional response to the object and their level of interest in it.
sitting on: Holding an object in hands while sitting.
Looking down at the object in hands.
Talking or communicating with someone while sitting.
sliding: Hand grasping the object: The person holds the object in their hand, providing the necessary grip and control for sliding.
Hand positioning: The person positions their hand correctly on the object, ensuring a smooth and controlled slide.
Body movement: The person shifts their body weight and moves their body in the direction of the slide, generating momentum and speed.
Foot placement: The person places their feet shoulder-width apart, providing stability and balance during the slide.
Eye contact: The person maintains eye contact with the direction of the slide, focusing on the intended path and ensuring proper alignment.
smelling: The person's head is tilted to the side, indicating that they are focusing on the object's scent.
The person's nose is wrinkled, which is a common response when smelling something strong or unfamiliar.
The person's mouth may be slightly open, as they breathe in the scent more deeply.
The person's eyes may be closed, as they concentrate on the sensation of the scent.
The person may be holding the object to their nose, or bringing it closer to their face, to enhance the smelling experience.
spinning: Hand movement: The person's hand(s) will be seen making circular or rotational motions as they spin the object.
Arm movement: The person's arm(s) will be seen moving in a circular or rotational motion as they spin the object.
Body rotation: The person's body will be seen rotating as they spin the object.
Finger movement: The person's fingers will be seen making precise movements as they grip and manipulate the object.
Balance: The person will need to maintain their balance while spinning the object, which may involve shifting their weight or adjusting their stance.
squeezing: Hand gripping the object: The hand of the person squeezing the object will be visible, with the fingers wrapped around the object and the thumb and index finger providing additional support.
Finger and thumb pressure: The person's fingers and thumb will apply pressure to the object, with the thumb on the bottom and the fingers on top.
Object deformation: The object being squeezed will show signs of deformation, such as wrinkles or creases, as the person applies pressure.
Muscle movement: The person's muscles will contract as they squeeze the object, causing the hand and arm to move in a coordinated manner.
Joint movement: The person's joints, including the wrist, elbow, and shoulder, will move in a coordinated manner as they apply pressure and squeeze the object.
stabbing: The person holding the object with a stabbing motion.
The person's hand and arm making a stabbing motion.
The object being stabbed by the person.
The person's face and body language indicating aggression and focus.
Any accompanying sounds or noises made by the person or the object being stabbed.
standing on: Balancing: The person is actively maintaining their balance on the object, which requires constant adjustments and concentration.
Climbing: The person is using their hands and feet to ascend the object, which requires strength, agility, and coordination.
Jumping: The person is using their legs to propel themselves off the ground and onto the object, which requires power and timing.
Dismounting: The person is getting off the object, which requires lower body strength and coordination to maintain stability.
Performing a trick or stunt: The person is using the object as a platform to perform a specific maneuver, which requires skill, practice, and control.
standing under: Crouching or bending the knees to lower the body height.
Holding onto the object for support or balance.
Looking up at the object or the sky above.
Reaching up to touch the object or to grab something hanging from it.
Standing still and observing the object or the surroundings.
sticking: Grasping the object: The person reaches out with their hand and places it around the object.
Holding the object: The person maintains a firm grip on the object with their hand.
Pulling the object: The person applies force to the object, causing it to move away from its original position.
Lifting the object: The person raises the object off the ground or a surface by exerting upward force.
Throwing the object: The person releases the object with force, causing it to travel through the air.
stirring: Raising the object above the surface: The person lifts the object above the surface, creating a clear visual indication of their action.
Rotating the object: As the person stirs, they may rotate the object in a circular motion, which can be seen and identified.
Striking the object: The person may strike the object with a spoon or other utensil, creating a distinct sound and visual cue.
Tipping the object: The person may tilt the object on its side, creating a visible change in its orientation.
Mixing the contents: As the person stirs, they may mix the contents of the object, creating a visible blending of the ingredients.
stopping at: The person's body position changes, with their feet stopping or slowing down, and their upper body continuing to move forward.
The person's eyes focus on the object, indicating their attention is drawn to it.
The person's hand may reach out or extend towards the object, either to touch it or to prepare to do so.
The person's mouth may open or their breathing may change as they process the situation and consider their next move.
The person's posture may change, with their weight shifting from their forward momentum to their newly stopped position.
straddling: Bending: The person may bend their knees and lower their body to get closer to the object.
Leaning: The person may lean forward or backward to get a better view or reach of the object.
Grasping: The person may reach out and grab the object with their hands.
Pulling: The person may use their strength to pull the object towards them.
Lifting: The person may lift the object off the ground or a surface by using their arms and upper body strength.
swinging: The person gripping the object with both hands.
The person raising the object above their head.
The person swinging the object forward and downward.
The person following through with the swing.
The person releasing the object after the swing.
tagging: Picking up the object: The person reaches out and grasps the object with their hand or another tool.
Holding the object: The person maintains a firm grip on the object while it is being tagged.
Positioning the tagging device: The person aligns the tagging device (such as a sticker or a label) with the object and prepares to apply it.
Applying the tag: The person presses down on the tagging device to adhere it to the object, making sure it is securely attached.
Removing the tagging device: The person carefully removes the tagging device from the object, ensuring that it is not damaged or left behind.
talking on: Hand holding the object to the ear.
The person's mouth moving in a speaking motion.
The person's eyes looking up and to the side, as if listening intently.
The person's body posture, such as leaning forward or sitting up straight, indicating their focus on the conversation.
The person's facial expression, which may show emotions such as happiness, surprise, or concern, depending on the content of the conversation.
teaching: Demonstrating the proper technique or method for using the object.
Encouraging and motivating the learner through verbal or non-verbal cues.
Providing feedback and correction as needed to ensure the learner is understanding and mastering the object.
texting on: Holding the object in one hand and using the other hand to type on the screen.
Using a stylus to write or draw on the object's surface.
Using a specialized app that allows the object to function as a virtual keyboard or touchpad.
Using the object as a makeshift stand for the phone or tablet to improve viewing angles.
Using the object to prop up the phone or tablet to create a more comfortable typing position.
throwing: The person's arm is raised and extended, with the object gripped firmly in their hand.
The person's body is rotating and pivoting on their feet, transferring their weight from the back foot to the front foot as they prepare to throw the object.
The person's eyes are focused on the target, and their head is angled towards it, as they line up the throw.
The person's mouth is open, and they may be making a sound, such as a grunt or a shout, to help them concentrate and generate power for the throw.
The person's arm is fully extended, and the object is released with a snap of the wrist, sending it flying towards the target.
tying: Bending the knees: As the person bends their knees, they lower their center of gravity, making it easier to tie the object securely.
Crossing the legs: The person may cross their legs while tying the object, which can help with balance and stability.
Holding the object: The person holds the object in one or both hands while tying it, ensuring that it remains steady and does not move around.
Bringing the ends together: The person brings the ends of the object together, creating a loop that can be tied.

Tying the knot: The person ties a knot in the loop to secure the object in place. This may involve using a specific technique, such as a slip knot or a bow knot, depending on the type of object being tied.
toasting: Raising the object above the head.
Holding the object in both hands.
Bringing the object close to the face.
Making a "cheers" gesture with the object.
training: Holding the object: The person is holding the object in their hands, which is a crucial step in training the object.
Observing the object: The person is closely observing the object, analyzing its features and characteristics to understand how it works and what it can be trained to do.
Gripping the object: The person is gripping the object firmly but not too tightly, which is important for maintaining control and preventing damage to the object during training.
Moving the object: The person is moving the object in a controlled and deliberate manner, which is necessary for teaching the object new behaviors and commands.

Reinforcing the object: The person is reinforcing the object by providing positive feedback or rewards, which helps to strengthen the bond between the person and the object and encourages the object to learn and perform new tasks.
turning: Gripping: The person holds the object with their hands, using a firm yet comfortable grip.
Rotating: The person uses their hands, arms, or body to rotate the object in a circular motion.
Twisting: The person applies pressure to the object and twists it in a spiral motion.
Pivoting: The person places one end of the object on a surface and uses their body weight to pivot it in a controlled manner.
Lifting: The person lifts the object off the ground or a surface and rotates it in the air before placing it back down.
typing on: Hand placement: The person's hands are likely positioned on the object, such as a keyboard or touchpad, to type.
Finger movement: The person's fingers are moving across the keys or touchpad to type letters and symbols.
Wrist movement: The person's wrist may be moving in a circular motion as they type, to help with the fluidity of their movements.
Eye movement: The person's eyes may be moving up and down as they read and type, to help with the process of reading and typing.
Head movement: The person's head may be moving slightly as they type, to help with the process of reading and typing.
walking: Picking up the object: The person reaches out with one or both hands and grasps the object.
Holding the object: The person maintains a firm grip on the object while it is being carried.
Lifting the object: The person bends their knees and lifts the object off the ground, using their strength and balance to support it.
Carrying the object: The person walks while holding the object, maintaining a steady gait and keeping the object close to their body.
Placing the object down: The person reaches their destination and carefully sets the object down on a flat, stable surface.
washing: Holding the object: The person holds the object above the water in a basin or sink.
Immersing the object: The person submerges the object in the water, ensuring that it is completely covered.
Rinsing the object: The person uses water to clean the object, removing any dirt or debris.
Drying the object: The person uses a towel or a hairdryer to dry the object, making sure that it is completely dry before use.
Storing the object: The person places the object in a safe and dry location, away from water and moisture, to prevent damage or deterioration.
watching: Observing: The person is actively looking at the object, focusing their attention on it.
Tracking: The person is following the object's movement, either in a static or dynamic environment.
Scanning: The person is quickly surveying the area to locate the object or to assess the situation.
Mapping: The person is mentally creating a visual representation of the environment, including the location of the object.
Recognizing: The person is identifying the object based on its features, shape, or color, and associating it with a particular category or object type.
waving: Raising arm: The person lifts their arm up to waive the object.
Extending arm: The person extends their arm outward to reach the object and make contact with it.
Holding object: The person holds the object in their hand while waving it.
Moving arm: The person moves their arm back and forth to create a waving motion.
Waving motion: The person's arm moves in a waving motion, typically in a circular or back-and-forth pattern.
wearing: Wearing a necklace around the neck.
Holding a cell phone in the hand.
Wearing a wristwatch on the wrist.
Putting on a pair of glasses.
Wearing a ring on the finger.
wielding: Grip: The way a person holds the object, which can provide insight into their level of control and comfort with the item.
Stance: The position of the body and the distribution of weight while holding the object, which can affect the power and accuracy of the swing.
Swing: The motion of the object being wielded, which can include the speed, direction, and force applied to the object.
Follow-through: The continuation of the swing after making contact with the target, which can affect the accuracy and consistency of the hit.
Reaction: The immediate response to the outcome of the swing, which can include the expression of surprise, satisfaction, or disappointment.
